Fields.DialogueText: What do you have there in your hand, Hull?
Bluebonnets! I had these picked up in port. Thought the ship could use some sprucing up.
Other than flowers?
Isn't that something! It's a turkey feather!

Fields.MenuText: It's beautiful!
What's so special about a turkey feather?
From a wild turkey?

Fields.DialogueText: Isn't it gorgeous! I bet this one came from a bearded tom, trying to impress a hen.
Let me invite you to a Thanksgiving dinner sometime and you'll understand!
Either that or these feathers came from a joint raising heritage breeds like bourbons.
Well, I think this would just be darling to frame it on my wall with some of these flowers. If I didn't know any better, I'd say this was from a Rio Grande turkey.
What makes you think that specific turkey?
These flowers are from Texas, and bluebonnets are of course the state flower... even though they go by many names. The math does itself.
*ALARM*
Don't be so sure. I've still got my heart set on that fireplace, you know...
@BATTLE
Might look nice around the fireplace.
Oh, rub it in, why don't you. Wait a minute... what's this in the bouquet?
Excited over a feather? That'll make your birthday easy to shop for.
What do you see through that spotting scope, Hull?
Oh, I was glassing for turkeys.
To hunt?
HA! I wish. Turkeys are nearly extinct in the wild. Fancy that, huh?
But I see turkey on the dinner table all the time.
Domesticated ones. Wild turkeys have nearly been hunted to extinction. People got greedy, ya know? Man, wouldn't that be swell if they could come back...
You don't think they would?
Nah. I mean, look at the passenger pigeon. They used to cover the sky, and they went extinct in 1914. Then there's the Carolina parakeet and the great auk, all gone the way of the dodo.
I heard dodos were too trusting.
They were the largest member of the pigeon family. Ever raise a baby pigeon?

Fields.MenuText: Yes, I love pigeons. I keep an immaculate loft.
Pigeons are rats with wings.
I don't think I've ever seen a baby pigeon.

Fields.DialogueText: Is that so? I'd love to hear all about it! Do you keep homers or fancy show breeds? I would just love to own some Scandaroons from Charles Darwin's loft.
You're more right than you know. Pigeons and rats are both intelligent and live in family groups.
You'd be hard pressed to. The parents usually nest in the scaffolding under bridges. Hard to reach.
Let me tell ya this: baby pigeons, the squeakers around 2-3 weeks old, look just like dodo birds. Honest!
What do baby turkeys look like?
They look similar to a baby guinea fowl. Nothing special at first, but they grow up to be great guards. Mostly because of their call.
*ALARM*
I definitely know which I'd prefer.
@BATTLE
Better than the alarm?
It's because they're family that I can be that way. You should hear what they say about me!
Maybe I'll do some sketches of this next time I write to my sisters.
It sure would. Then I'd get a sketch of Aylwin's Inverted Jenny stamp, Worden would do something neat with her swords...
You're a competitive family.
It keeps us close. When we're all together, it's like a big old craft exchange.
Not often you hear about the things warships create. I'd love to see what you all come up with.
Hmm.
No, Cap, you're right. It just got me thinking. I like blowing stuff up, don't get me wrong. All the girls do. But we can't constantly be in war mode.
*ALARM*
There's your answer.
The Morganas, or the alarm? Loud son of a gun...
@BATTLE
That feather's a nice touch with the flower display.
I figured it might be. Flowers and feathers might not be the most alike things in the world, but you can tell when things have the same home. They go together.
Like you and your sisters.
I'll allow that some of them can be real turkeys.

Fields.MenuText: Don't be that way. They're family.
What's that make you?
That bad, huh?

Fields.DialogueText: A majestic eagle, of course! Just what America needs right now.
Not bad. Stubborn, sure. Annoying, sometimes. But they've always got each other's backs, and I've always got theirs. We flock together.
That'd be nice. It'd let them know you're thinking of them.
Sorry, was that rude?
You know, you might have a point. In which case, why are we awake?
If you were, you wouldn't have awakened.
Careful there, Captain. One slip and the whole project's cracked.
What's in the crate?
Here, take a look. I swapped an officer my rum ration to pick it up in port.
Eggs?
Turkey eggs, to be specific.
Where did you find these?
I could hardly believe the rumor myself when I heard it. But there's no mistaking the speckles. These could be some of the last in the country... maybe in the world!

Fields.MenuText: Is the sea really a place for them?

Fields.DialogueText: Far away from anyone who might want to eat them, and surrounded by guns for those who do. There's nowhere safer.
What are we going to do with breeding pairs of turkeys?
Make sure they're alive to breed. I wrote to the Department of the Interior just the other day to sell the project.
Hull, I really don't think-

Fields.MenuText: So... scrambled or poached?

Fields.DialogueText: No more cracks like that. This is serious!

Fields.MenuText: I've heard of ships' cats, but not ships' turkeys.

Fields.DialogueText: What can I say, Cap? I'm a trailblazer.
*ALARM*
It'll be fine, Captain. I've got it all under control!
No sense arguing. For now.
@BATTLE
Cap, I need your opinion on something. Do you think this room would work?
What type of plan are you hatching this time?
Answered your own question there, didn't you?
You're serious about this, aren't you?
Like a hole in my hull.
How are you going to keep the eggs warm?
I'm going to use some stock troughs lined with straw and goose down in addition to a heat lamp. Then there's just turning the eggs and monitoring the humidity to worry about.

Fields.MenuText: What if the eggs are too humid?
What if the eggs are too dry?
Are you sure the eggs will be warm enough?

Fields.DialogueText: If the eggs are too humid, I'll put a fan up. That's a particular problem out here.
If they're too dry, I'll spray the straw with some water to increase the humidity levels.
Goose down should retain the heat, but I can always add more heat lamps!
Collecting flowers is one thing, but this? I can't help but think it's... odd.
I couldn't help but think, either. What you said about me and my sisters... If we were all about fighting, we wouldn't have awakened.
*ALARM*
Sounds like you've got it under control. Will those eggs be safe during a fight?
@BATTLE
Destruction's all well and good. But it's on us to do something constructive as long as we're able.
Besides, fighting for my country's not just about putting shells where they belong. It's about protecting what makes it unique.
Otherwise, why even have a country?
I knew you'd understand, Cap!
We'll find out. High risk, high reward.
Whew. No worse for wear in these waters.
The eggs?
I packed them just right. It'll take more than a storm or a bombardment to crack these babies.

Fields.MenuText: You build a good nest.
Like what?
What if we have to abandon ship?

Fields.DialogueText: You gotta pack 'em tight, but not so tight they crack. Nature's all about balance.
If I have anything to say about it, we're never finding out.
Then you guard these eggs with your life, Cap. I'm counting on you!
How many eggs do you have again?
Three dozen. Account for a 90 percent hatch rate if they're all fertile and there should be 32 eggs hatching.
How do you tell which ones are fertile?
Candling. You can light them up and see if there's any defects. That calls for a light source... and another box.
We won't be able to check for about five days, so I've got plenty of time to make one. Maybe some of those ammo boxes I have lying around...
If something's good, you make it last. Waste not, want not.
@BATTLE
Always another box, isn't it?
There should be no shortage of those. You've really got a way of putting old things to use.
If the Navy knows what's good for it, they'll keep that in mind for you Belles.
*ALARM*
Don't you worry, Cap. We're not going anywhere.
Hull, where are you?
Okay, belay that. I know you're in here. I can smell lavender.
Good nose!
Why is it so dark in this room?
I'm candling the eggs! And so far, so good - they're all fertile. Looks like some of my sisters might be getting extras.

Fields.MenuText: Why are you doing this in the dark?
We couldn't keep the extra four for food?
How far along are the eggs?

Fields.DialogueText: That's how you see through the eggs! I'm looking for a little shadow and some vascularity. It's sterile without those.
I'm hatching these birds for breeding, not keeping them to eat. Think long term, Captain.
By this estimation, I'd say five to seven days. Good thing I gave 'em room to grow - these things get big!
Good news, Cap: all the eggs are fertile! Let's put them back into the incubator. I'll come back later and turn them.
I'm surprised you have time for that.
Aboard this ship I can appear wherever I need to, remember? Comes in handy. Just like a mama bird, I need to turn the eggs at least thrice a day.
Are you going to be there for when they hatch?
Somebody is. I trust a few of the crew to keep watch when I can't. And these guys are like chickens - once they hatch, they immediately start looking for food.
I'll see if we can get some seeds in port.
*ALARM*
Appreciate it, Cap. Now, let's deal with these Morganas before they wake the chicks up early!
@BATTLE
Would you look at that sky...
It looks red.
That's what they say. Red sky at morning, sailors take warning.
Is there a reason for that?
That reddish glow comes from storm clouds. They're over to the west, and the morning sun is to the east.
A red sky at night is a sailor's delight because the storm has already passed.

Fields.MenuText: This means a storm is coming our way?
I didn't think there was any truth behind this.
Then why does the sky look red around the sun?

Fields.DialogueText: I think a storm is headed our way. We should batten our stuff down.
There's truth in everything if you dig deep enough.
That's just light bouncing back. Think of it like the moon - it reflects the sun's light from behind the earth.
Now, if I'm right about the weather - and I usually am - I need to go check on the eggs. Humidity, and all that.
*ALARM*
Back in a jiffy. We only get one shot with these eggs!
@BATTLE
Make it quick. There's more than just a storm on the way.
We only get one shot in a battle.
We get several, Captain, and we're going to make them all count.
Got it, Captain!
Not yet, you don't! Get after it!
It's rolling into the kitchen! Everyone, stop that egg, but don't break it!
It's too fast! How does an egg roll this fast?
Watch out! Don't let it crack!
And... caught it! Let's put this little gem back into the incubator where it belongs.

Fields.MenuText: How did that egg roll away?
Is the egg going to be all right?
Why worry about one egg?

Fields.DialogueText: Must have been a rogue wave. The waters are choppy today.
I don't see why not. These babies are resilient. Now, if I were hatching snakes we'd be in trouble.
If this egg hatches and it's a hen, it can contribute to a few dozen more turkeys over the course of her life. The numbers add up.
What were you doing, anyway?
It was my shift on watch. I was keeping an eye out for the Morganas bearing down on us now.
@BATTLE
Catch that egg! Don't let it roll away!
I'm here! I've got it!
*ALARM*
You couldn't have led with that?
Don't judge my to-do list!
... And that about does it for that report. Anything I missed?
Nah, it's not that. These eggs are more work than I was expecting. All this turning and checking on temperatures... how do turkey hens do it?
I think turkey hens don't have to worry about defeating Morganas.
Yeah, I think I favor the guinea hen approach.
What do you mean by that?
Communal nesters. The chicks are everyone's chicks. That's why I appreciate the sailors' help. I couldn't do it alone.

Fields.MenuText: Why not use domestic turkeys to incubate the eggs?
What are we going to do with thirty-two turkeys?
Think of all the feathers!

Fields.DialogueText: I don't hear any talk of domestic turkeys being broody like hens. I want something broody that will take to setting on these eggs like a duck to water.
Keep them safe and fed until we can hand them off.
I bet I could tie some into a few fishing flies and catch me a nice trout when I have time. We just need to hatch the little guys first.
Did you hear back from the Department of the Interior about them?
We may be fighting for humanity, but I'm fighting for America too. These birds are the symbol of Thanksgiving. What's more American than that?
@BATTLE
I didn't think it was that tough of a battle.
Oh! Sorry, Cap. I'm having trouble focusing. Just a little tired, is all.
Hull?
Wonderful. Now we've got a government mandate to see your project through.
Yep! They've approved a grant for my expenses.
*ALARM*
Keep it up and you'll save more than one species.
You see the mail today, Cap? My sisters are starting to take notice.
They're not the only ones. Your turkeys came up in the San Diego Union's war bulletin.
You can find them in every war if you look hard enough. I was just reading about mil-spec pigeons, actually...

Fields.MenuText: There are mil-spec pigeons?
So you're getting pigeons?
I don't suppose turkeys would serve some kind of military purpose?

Fields.DialogueText: There certainly are! Night flyers, spec-ops birds... they can be more useful than radio if the enemy's listening.
Nah, they're not useful at the ranges we work with. Haven't been since the 20s.
Not a whole hell of a lot. If you think of one, let me know.
They're kind of a dead end technology-wise. Once the enemy starts training hawks for interception, where can you really go?
So once we're done with them, I guess it's back to-
Saving more endangered North American species?
I was going to say hunting, but I suppose those can intersect.
*ALARM*
Well, I know what I'm doing after the fight. I've got seven letters to respond to. Remind me to tell you about Aylwin's stamp search...
@BATTLE
Ooh! Lemme see, lemme see!
It's a pretty brief mention. Then it goes into detail about the military applications of birds. It's... interesting.
A bit.
Surprised?
That's why I'm sending one to each of my sisters. Half the fun of our little fixations is sharing them.
It's still interesting. I can see why you like birds so much.
What's that noise? Is there something wrong with the engines?
Oh, goodness! My chickens have arrived! Let's get these gals to work. Is the food there as well?
More birds?
To help incubate. I ordered some scratch grain for them, too. Can't let these working gals starve.
Speaking of which, we need to get in some food for the turkeys. It'll be ready by the time they hatch!
What do turkeys eat? It's not the same as chickens?
Mostly, but they need more protein. Hence the grasshoppers I ordered.
That's funny. I thought you said grasshoppers.
I figured I'd get some flown in from Thailand. They're supposed to have huge ones there!
Hmm... roasted grasshoppers don't sound so bad.
Nah, they need to be alive. Young turkeys need movement.

Fields.MenuText: This sounds like just as much work as turning eggs over all day.
Turkeys, then chickens, and now grasshoppers. What's next?
I guess if they work out as a food supply, we could breed those too.

Fields.DialogueText: It won't be that much work. Just put some grasshoppers in a screen box with a lid to hold water and some leaves.
The bald eagle could certainly use our help! It doesn't get more American than that.
Let me know if it's any good. I bet it ain't no New York cheesecake.
Well, it's Uncle Sam's money, not yours.
@BATTLE
It's for a good cause, Cap. And speaking of earning my keep, I think we can get the drop on these Morganas...
You're fine. I was hoping you'd be the officer with my grasshoppers.
Sorry to disappoint?
You might look into wearing some perfume yourself. This way I know when you're coming.

Fields.MenuText: Lavender isn't really my thing.
I guess identifying someone by smell has its benefits.
I figure by the time this is all over, I'll smell like turkey.

Fields.DialogueText: Certainly not my perfume. That'd just confuse everyone.
You know who's in the room without even asking! Most communication's nonverbal, anyway.
Not if you keep clean, you won't.
Miss Hull, I thought I smelled your lavender perfume in here. Here is the box of grasshoppers you ordered.
*ALARM*
If only the Morganas had a distinctive smell.
They don't need one. Their aura's so depressing you can taste it.
@BATTLE
I can come back.
Whoa! What's with the sneaking?
Hull, I wonder if-
Excellent work, officer!
Still no hard feelings about the egg?
Could have happened to anyone. Don't worry about it!
Hull? Hull! We have a problem on our hands.
I'm... here... Captain. Whew, I'm out of breath. I was trying to catch all the escaped grasshoppers.
Should I even ask how they escaped?
I think it's from the last Morgana battle we had. Their box must have gotten knocked around.
Try to get rid of them if you can.
I do have the best aim of anyone aboard.
Don't shoot at them!
Who said anything about shooting? I'm going to use this butterfly net I requisitioned.

Fields.MenuText: These grasshoppers are going to get into everything, I just know it!
How much longer until those turkeys hatch, again?
Someone at the Department of the Interior's going to have a lot of questions.

Fields.DialogueText: If you manage to swallow a few on accident, let me know what they taste like. I haven't gotten around to trying them.
No rushing life, Captain. These things take time.
When this is all over, my requisitions are going to make a hilarious book. I'll dedicate it to all the pencil pushers.
Just get the grasshoppers as quickly as possible!
Already on it! Come here, you little jerks...
*ALARM*
Teleportation, remember? I'll catch up once this box is full!
@BATTLE
Ah, here she comes. I thought I smelled lavender.
Gah! What the hell is with all these grasshoppers!?
Hull-
*BOOM*
... Half full.
Whew, that report took forever. Time for a nap... Gah! Hull!
I came as soon as I heard! What's the problem?
There are grasshoppers in my bed!
So that's where those little buggers went to! Thanks for finding them for me, Cap!
I thought you were going to get all the grasshoppers taken care of.
So did I. These must be the last ones... I think.
You think.
You can never be so sure with nature. Life finds a way.

Fields.MenuText: Life is about to find a way to the bottom of my boot!
If life finds a way, then why are these wild turkeys so endangered?
Life needs to get of my room so I can catch forty winks.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't say that! Think how much of a pain it will be to clean your boot off.
Human life found a way first.
Don't work yourself up so much that you won't be able to fall asleep. I can tell you need it.
*ALARM*
Fine. I wasn't going to get a nap anyway.
@BATTLE
I'll handle the grasshoppers after the fight, Cap. In fact, I'm confining you to your quarters until I'm sure I've handled them.
Can you even do that?
Belle's veto applies if you're incapacitated. The law doesn't specifically exclude sleep deprivation, you know...
Another grasshopper? Oh, goodness. Don't let the captain find out about this.
Find out about what?
Oh... err... you're not supposed to know, ya know?

Fields.MenuText: I'm the captain of this ship. I need to know everything.
Just make sure it's good news when I do know.
I can see that grasshopper in your hand, Hull.

Fields.DialogueText: But then it won't be a surprise!
You'll be the first to get it. Well, second.
Oh, this one? Thought I'd... take it for a walk, you- whoa!
I have a feeling that I'll still be finding grasshoppers in six months.
Think of how many turkeys we can hatch in that time!
It looks like it just walked off.
Ideally enough to deal with these grasshoppers.
You know, I did confine you to your quarters until the grasshopper thing was solved.
Don't give me that. Did you even know they were still loose?
One thing about nature, Captain. Fail to adapt to the environment and you're out of luck. Now, shoo!
*ALARM*
What was that about adaptation?
I'm the captain. That hasn't turned.
The parameters of a situation can turn on a dime.
Damn Morganas. Arms races are like that too.
@BATTLE
Captain? Are you decent?
People usually ask that before coming into a room.
Oh, my eyes were averted.
Anyway, Captain, I have some wonderful news!

Fields.MenuText: The turkeys are gone?
The turkey eggs are doing well?
The Morganas are gone?

Fields.DialogueText: Not until I'm sure they've got good homes!
Better than well, thanks to you and me and the whole crew!
If only. Then I could raise more turkeys.
The turkeys are growing! Not as in the eggs getting larger, but they are growing on the inside.
Grasshoppers?
I was thinking more along the line of mealworms and sunflower seeds. The sunflower seeds will be easy to get, but the mealworms... different story.
Oh, well, that's all right, then.
Ooh, those hens deserve some treats!
I'd appreciate it if we could do without more insects.
If you've got an alternative, I'm all ears.
Can we mince some carrots or something?
See, this is why we work so well together. I won't even need to requisition those from the Interior guys.
They've already bankrolled butterfly nets and grasshoppers. What's a few carrots?
It's like a friend taking me to lunch. I don't like going overboard if someone else is paying.
Even if that someone is a government?
No reason to make Aylwin jealous, anyway. The Smithsonian denied her stamp collecting grant application.
Not as culturally significant as the turkeys, I take it.
Oh, the museum folks fought over it. Secretary Abbot himself was the final no on the subject. Aylwin's still stewing.
*ALARM*
Get decent, Captain. There's a fight on!
Wait, how did... never mind.
@BATTLE
Look at these chickens!
They're chickens, all right.
And for their service to my turkey eggs, it's time to give them their treats.
Thank goodness we decided against the mealworms. I don't know if I could take those.
Minced carrots and sunflower seeds are easier. You know, I reckon I might have a future in agriculture once we're done here.
Farmer Hull. It does have a nice ring to it.
Farmer, park ranger, conservationist... the sky's the limit.
Do something for me, though, will you?
What's that?
Don't let the older ships know about this. I can hear it now... "Oh, look at old Goldplater, trying to get her college diploma!"
Oh, I know there's no shame. That's why they have to go around inventing it.

Fields.MenuText: What does your nickname have to do with your education?
I bet they're just jealous of your skills.
I never thought of ships as... catty.

Fields.DialogueText: Just one more way they can make fun of me for daring to be better, I guess.
Ain't none of them a better shot than me or half as comfy. Right?
Lot of empty ocean out here. Some of us fill our time better than others.
Some folks don't see the value in repairing and repurposing, Cap. Simple as that. Why improve something old when you can just roll out something new?
Educated guesses. Keep 'em coming!
@BATTLE
There's no shame in going back to school. You're never too old for an education.
But you're an improvement on those older destroyers in just about every way.
*ALARM*
And that's what makes some of us feel trapped. I am what I am, so why try and be more?
I understand where it comes from. But you can keep it far away from me. There's no problem so new I can't learn to lick it.
The Morganas certainly keep us guessing.
You must have memorized that flower scrapbook of yours by now.
It's familiar. Always cheers me up whenever anyone brings up that Goldplater nonsense.
What flower is that pink one there?
Chinese peony. You see all those layers?
What about that other pink one there?
Good old camellia sinensis.
What about that white one?
Chrysanthemum. See the compound petals? They might be my favorite.
There's a lot of complexity in such a simple plant. But there's more to it than that. You know they bloom in the late summer and early fall, yeah?
Pretty late for a flower.
Better late than never. And that way there's not as many other flowers waiting around to be pollinated. More for them.

Fields.MenuText: Are bees even around that late?
Survival of the fittest, eh?
What do bees look for in flowers?

Fields.DialogueText: Not all winter, but they can warm each other up before they swarm.
For a given environment, yeah. You couldn't put a fish in the desert and judge it that way.
Depends on the bee. Longer tongues, different flowers.
But I really respect the resilience of those mums. They stick around longer than people think they should and bloom all the brighter for it.
You know, you're not wrong. I'll let you have that one.
@BATTLE
Tea.
Bless you.
You like the really big flowers, don't you?
Regular goldplaters, aren't they?
*ALARM*
Captain... Captain!
Hull!? Why are you waking me up at this hour?
The eggs are hatching!
Well, what are we waiting for? Show me the magic!
No, that wouldn't be practical. I don't want to disturb my hens. I just needed to share it with someone.

Fields.MenuText: Right. The hens get to be left alone.
Do you ever sleep?
I guess it's worth losing a little sleep over.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be like that, Cap. They don't get breaks.
I nap during the day. Kind of like a giraffe.
I'll make it up to you, Captain. It just felt wrong to leave you out of the end of all this.
I'm happy for you, Hull. Now if you wouldn't mind...
Captain?
What!?
Do you think I should wake the officers to let them know the eggs are hatching?
I can't speak for them. Why don't you find out?
*ALARM*
Captain!
All right, you win this one. But I'm setting your alarm clock five minutes early.
@BATTLE
Aren't these little chicks the cutest?
I thought you liked scents like lavender?
It's my favorite to wear, but I'm not about to shoot flowers at the Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: Could you?
Can't you selectively breed birds to have special scents?
I could go for a turkey leg right about now...

Fields.DialogueText: There's poetry in bullets that grow flowers where they fall, but that ain't happening out here.
I've never heard anyone breeding birds for scent before. That just seems like a whole lot of misplaced effort.
Get your own turkey! These guys are for my sisters and for Uncle Sam.
Well, enough fawning. I should make sure the room temperature's good for them.
The bedding should help with that.
That's remarkably informative bedding you've got there.
What about your perfume?
They can't smell it. Besides, you know I keep it subtle.
*ALARM*
Among many other things. I guess I'll shred these papers later.
@BATTLE
You'll get used to it. To me it smells like success. Maybe even... the future.
They don't smell cute.
Wouldn't want them to catch any drafts.
And this week. I was kind of interested in the war bulletin.
Issues of the Union! I've been collecting them from the past few weeks.
Sorry, Cap. I thought you'd read it already.
Bad for their lungs.
You can't use wood chips?
That's what separates you from the Morganas.
Would you look at that rainbow! Hull, do you see it?
I sure do.
What does this mean? You're the weather expert.
Rainbow in the morning, sailors take warning. Rainbow at night, sailors' delight. Rainbow at noon, rain very soon.
So what does this rainbow mean here?
What time did you say it was again, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Mid-morning.
It's getting late in the day.
Time to get yourself a watch.

Fields.DialogueText: Then it's going to rain soon. We'd better prepare the ship so we're ready to battle in these conditions.
Then it should be smooth sailing for us, Captain.
I'll just steal yours. How about that?
I thought you'd be more conscious of the time of day.
My fault, Captain. I've been so cooped up with the birds that I've lost track of time.
Heh. Cooped up.
Any normal day I'd seriously consider throwing you to the Morganas for that.
There's no such thing as "any normal day" anymore. Not while you're around.
Oh, shucks, Captain, you're going to make me blush.
It's true. Strange as all this has been, you've saved a whole lot of lives - and not just human lives.
Make no mistake. If it means saving something that's important to you and your people, I can take a few grasshoppers.
I'm glad, Cap. But we'd better make dead sure those grasshoppers are off the ship. The turkeys aren't going to be around much longer.
That soon?
*ALARM*
Soon, Captain. But not now.
@BATTLE
You see the latest from the Interior Department?
I did. You need me to hand the turkeys off?
Nah, I'll be there for it. I asked for the handoff to happen aboard me.
It must be hard saying goodbye.
I knew they weren't mine to keep, Captain. They've got a bigger destiny than being my feathered friends. It's just... knowing and doing are two different things.

Fields.MenuText: I was just starting to like having them around.
Anything in mind to replace them?
I'm going to miss them. It was like having our own mascots.

Fields.DialogueText: They liked you too, Cap. I think they'd started perking up every time it was your turn to feed them.
It's back to the drawing board for now. I'm going to need time to figure out accommodations for bigger animals.
We had our time with them, Captain. Now it's America's turn.
So where do the turkeys go from here?
Newport News, Virginia. There's a wildlife preserve willing to take them all on.
We've still got grasshoppers?
Can't hear you, Captain! I think those Morganas want some turkey!
@BATTLE
They didn't want them. They all wrote back saying I'd find a better use for them. And I think I have, Cap.
All of them? I thought your sisters were getting some of them.
Nope. But it's something to look forward to, for us and for the folks back home. My sisters are pretty different, but we can all see that.
We won't know for a few years yet.
Besides, it's not like we're purging all the birds. We still need the hens to take care of the grasshoppers.
Relax, Captain. The feds are gone.
I'm relaxed. Are you?
Working on it.

Fields.MenuText: You named them, didn't you.
They're in good hands.
We'll find something else that needs saving.

Fields.DialogueText: Only Isaac! ... And Derby. And Laurel.
You're right, Captain. It's just... well, my hands were really good.
A Belle's work is never done.
Well, add one more address to my Christmas card list.
I had a feeling this wouldn't be the last of the turkeys.
That's the goal. Whenever that might be... well, I hope you and I aren't around to see it.
And here I thought you were going to live forever.
Nothing's forever, Captain. Eventually even I'm going to be broken up.
You? The pinnacle of warship design?
*ALARM*
Sometimes I wonder about that, Captain... but let's leave those thoughts for another day.
@BATTLE
The pinnacle of a very particular warship design. Not a lot of call for Farragut-classes in space, whenever you get around to fighting up there.
But building something that outlives me... if there's a way to live forever, that's it.
That's what separates you Belles from the Morganas. You're here to create things, and they're not.
I hope we never do.
We'll get you to the future if it's the last thing we do. What you do with it is your choice. The Belles aren't going to live forever.
I've never seen you so excited to make port.
Oh, I can't wait! That moose is ready and waiting for a new home.
Not living moose, that's sure. I'm talking about the one I bagged a while back! They've been holding it for me back in New York.

Fields.MenuText: Once again, where are you going to put a fireplace for display?
You must get preferential treatment as a Belle.
It's been a while since you had some proper cheesecake, hasn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: I'll talk to some eggheads about a chimney. Once I solve that, it's just a matter of picking out the right wood paneling.
Being me has its perks, but that's one I'm content not to use. To the taxidermist, I'm just a very good customer.
My mouth's watering just thinking about it! I think we've both earned some after this adventure.
Well, while we're on the subject of decoration... I thought I'd help you out.
Whoa! Captain, where did you get those peony seeds?
Pulled some strings while we were in the Pacific. I thought growing your own would be easier than trying to ship fully grown ones.
And more satisfying besides. Wait... are these...
Feathers, from the turkey chicks. They're small, but they're-
Perfect! Oh, I can't wait until I get it all arranged. My sisters are going to be so jealous!
It's just swell, Captain. And I know exactly where I'll put them... well, for now, anyway.
We'll get you that fireplace, Hull.
@BATTLE
We are not transporting moose at sea.
You've done some pretty great things out here, Hull. If I can help you do them... well, mission accomplished.
We can take our time on that, Cap. I think we'll have a lot of it.
*ALARM*
